page.title: 01"Bowcombe"-Isle of Wight.
page.content: The area that we have called{ {Bowcombe}after the only small hamlet within its boundaries, lies to the south-west of{Newport;}the Island's principal town. It is{mainly {agricultural land,}consisting of four farms contained mainly within it, and some land belonging to farms outside. The rest of the area; roughly one quarter, consists of{forest,}most of this being coniferous managed by the Forestry Commission, and some deciduous woodland. The area is a {valley,}hence the suffix "combe", with gently undulating hills on either side of the single road which winds along the valley floor. The nature of the area with its small population makes it ideal for walking. It has one major landmark; the tall mast of{Rowridge:} the BBC radio and television transmitter.
